botanical_details.genus: Rosa can be deciduous or semi-evergreen shrubs or scrambling climbers, with usually thorny stems bearing compound pinnate leaves and solitary or clustered flowers. Flowers may be followed by showy red or purple fruits in some varieties.
botanical_details.horticultural_group: Hybrid Tea, or Large-flowered bush roses are upright, thorny shrubs with large, usually glossy leaves and large, double often fragrant flowers that may be solitary or in threes

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grows best in fertile, humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil in a sunny open position. Mulch in late winter, and to improve flowering, apply a balanced fertiliser in late winter or early spring and again in early summer; see rose cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by semi-ripe cuttings, hardwood cuttings or by chip budding
how_to_grow.pests: Aphids, including rose aphid, are the most common pest. Can also be affected by rose leafhopper, glasshouse red spider mite, scale insects, caterpillars, large rose sawfly, rose leaf-rolling sawfly and leaf-cutter bees. Deer and rabbits can also cause damage
how_to_grow.diseases: Rose black spot, rose rust and rose powdery mildew are the most common diseases. Can also be affected by rose dieback, replant disease, honey fungus, a canker and a virus
